summary: This document is an email exchange from November 24, 2021, in which Gail Goodman, a Distinguished Professor of Psychology, provides her curriculum vitae and a list of federal court trials where she testified as an expert witness for the prosecution. She explains a psychological effect where misinformation can sometimes strengthen accurate memory for personally significant events, referencing her research on long-term memory for child sexual abuse experiences.

persons.name: Gail Goodman
persons.role: Expert Witness / Distinguished Professor of Psychology
persons.context: She is providing her professional background and expert testimony history to an unspecified recipient, and explaining her research findings on memory, particularly regarding child sexual abuse experiences.

events.title: Email correspondence providing expert witness information
events.description: Gail Goodman sends an email with her vita and a list of federal court trials where she testified as an expert witness for the prosecution, along with an explanation of her research on memory and misinformation.

locations: University of California (affiliation of Gail Goodman)
keyFacts: Gail Goodman is a Distinguished Professor and Director of the Center for Public Policy Research in the Department of Psychology at the University of California.
She has testified as an expert witness in federal court trials exclusively for the prosecution, never for the defense.
Her research includes the study of long-term memory for child sexual abuse experiences.
She describes a psychological finding where misinformation can, in some cases, make memory for personally significant events more accurate by contrast.
The document is marked as subject to a protective order covering specific paragraphs (7, 8, 9, 10, 15, and 17).
